original_content:
You know what they say. But its 2024, after all. Shouldnt you be able to tune a fish by now? As [ChromaLock] shows us in the video below, its absolutely possible, and has been all along.
Of course, you cant possibly put a rainbow trout (or any other fish) under tension until it produces audible tones. So, how does it work? [ChromaLock] turned to the skin, which functions electrically much like ours does with different resistance values in different areas.
From there, it was a matter of hunting around for spots that produced different notes that sounded good, and marking them for later so it can be played like a potentiometer. But there were problems with this setup, mostly screeching between notes from stray voltages in the environment.
After a brief detour using a PS/2 keyboard with spray-painted keycaps, [ChromaLock] said to hell with it and unearthed a regular MIDI keyboard. Armed with a 3D printed jig to hold the probes, [ChromaLock] tested everything with a cucumber, and then out came the trout for its musical debut. Be sure to check it out after the break.
What else can you do with canned tuna and other fish? Cook up some pyrolized bread, and youve got yourself a foundry and crucible.


Thanks to [Zixxorb] for the tip!
title: 魚を使った音楽デバイスの製作方法
body: 2024年、魚を調整可能にする方法が紹介された。皮を触れることで音を出す。電気的に私たちの肌と同じように機能し、異なる抵抗値を持つ場所で音を調整し、MIDIキーボードで演奏。焼き上がったパンで工場を作るアイデアも。
titles: 魚を使った音楽デバイスの製作方法
レギュラーのMIDIキーボードで魚を演奏する
魚の皮を使った音楽インタフェースの開発
魚を楽器として利用する方法
3Dプリントジグを使った魚の演奏テクニック
